captions.text:
Remember how a while back I said we should
stop using the phrase &#39;Dark Souls clone&#39;?

Just like I once said we should stop saying
&#39;Grand Theft Auto clone&#39; and then Sleeping

Dogs came out and I had to say &#39;Spoke too
fucking soon&#39;.

I&#39;ve got nothing left if I can&#39;t call Salt
&amp; Sanctuary a Dark Souls clone.

If it put a banana on its head I could call
it that game that&#39;s got a banana on its head

but until that day let&#39;s stick with Dark Souls
clone.

Games like Bloodborne and Lords of the Fallen
are certainly Dark Souls-esque but nothing

less than &quot;clone&quot; feels adequate for Salt
&amp; Sanctuary, the only main difference being
the paltry fact that it&#39;s a 2D platformer.

That sounds like a pretty fucking significant
difference to me, Yahtzee.

Well of course you&#39;d think that, voice in
my head, you&#39;re obviously a technically-minded

sort or you wouldn&#39;t keep trying to get me
to buy knives.

A third dimension does not a Dark Souls make;
Dark Souls is in the tone, the muddy visuals,

the grim, futile atmosphere of an anxiety
dream of a medieval knight with galloping
syphilis.

There are plenty of gameplay differences,
and there&#39;s the fact that Dark Souls never

had a super deformed character art style reminiscent
of an edgy webcomic from the early 2000s drawn

by someone who wasn&#39;t very good at anatomy
but considered it very important that there

exist a picture of furry Jesus Christ trying
to free his knob from a stillborn foetus,

But despite all that there are moments when
Salt &amp; Sanctuary could almost be a direct

2D adaptation of Dark Souls with the names
changed into slightly shittier ones.

Quick example, Blighttown was a good name
for a ramshackle colony on a poisonous bog.
&quot;Mire of Stench&quot;, not so much.

&#39;Cos it&#39;s kinda redundant and immediately
reminds me of that David Bowie film.

Anyway, in Salt &amp; Sanctuary you are drowning
in semen.
Oop, my mistake.

In Salt &amp; Sanctuary you are A drowning seamen
who wakes up after the traditional impossible

opening boss fight to find themselves on the
shore of a mysterious haunted land consisting

of fragments of dead civilizations crammed
together like six piglets in a duffel bag,

populated by the undead and the occasional
top half of a person grafted onto something

that isn&#39;t one of the very small number of
things it is appropriate for the top half
of a person to be grafted onto.

You set off to find the princess you were
supposed to be escorting but the game puts

very little effort into pretending that that
is the actual plot.

So we set off to explore the open-ended landscape
and gather salt from our enemies, which is

different to &#39;souls&#39; because you can&#39;t put
souls on your chips but otherwise it&#39;s just

as useful for upgrading our character at bonfires,
whoops I mean sanctuaries.

When you die you lose all your salt, which
is a bit counter-intuitive because getting

killed makes me pretty fucking salty, and
also a percentage of your money.

Ah, there&#39;s something different, in Dark Souls
you charge everything to your souls account

whereas in Salt &amp; Sanctuary money and salt
are separate things.

I&#39;m not sure why, though, &#39;cos the only things
money can buy are low-level items that stop

being useful about thirty seconds into the
game and you do all your weapon upgrading

with salt and with specific items of vendor
trash that dying enemies puke out like reverse

vacuum cleaners, so every time I died and
the game waggled its finger informing me that

it was taking a percentage of my cash I&#39;d
be all like &quot;Oh no.
Please don&#39;t.

I hate having to manually pull my trousers
down.&quot;

Another difference is that you can populate
sanctuaries with NPC vendors and must decide

if it&#39;s worth giving up a precious blacksmith
token to be able to get your sword upgraded
at the summit of Mount Bumfuck.

Except there&#39;s also a vendor who lets you
teleport between sanctuaries, so just put

one of those in as many places as you can
and stick all the other vendors in one or

two of the nice sanctuaries with the affordable
beachfront real estate.

Now, you understand I&#39;m not complaining that
a game is reminiscent of Dark Souls because

me and Dark Souls is like your mum and pies,
but certain important things are lost in the
shift to 2D.

For example, Salt &amp; Sanctuary could really
do with a fucking map.

Dark Souls can&#39;t have one &#39;cos there&#39;s too
much verticality, but it also doesn&#39;t really
need one &#39;cos it&#39;s got the scenery porn thing.

&quot;Better look around and figure out where I
am.

Oh I remember now, I&#39;m in a fantasy nightmare
world and I&#39;m making my way towards that vast
brick phallus in the distance.

Gosh, can&#39;t wait to find out how many things
want to murder me there.&quot;
You don&#39;t have that in 2D.

In 2D what you&#39;ve got is &quot;Gosh, I can&#39;t wait
to see what&#39;s past this twenty feet of stairway
I&#39;m currently looking at.&quot;

In Dark Souls whenever I warped to an old
bonfire I never had to wander about a few

minutes trying to remember where the fuck
I was in relation to everywhere else.
So, map please.
You don&#39;t have to be a pushover about it.

Make it kinda abstract or fire scorpions at
my mouth every time I look at it.

Combat obviously loses some complexity in
2D but Salty Sancho admirably recreates the

most important characteristics of Souls combat,
by which I mean, dodge-rolling behind people

as they attack always works and the hitboxes
are absolutely fucked.

Where the combat rubs up against the border
between Dark Souls town and Symphony of the

Night ville is when you get hit by a heavy
attack and your character goes flying gaily

across the screen like a happy little tear
gas canister at a protest against police brutality.

Which wasn&#39;t that annoying in Symphony of
the Night because there was no fall damage,

but guess what there&#39;s gobs of in Salty Sancho,
along with a platforming emphasis that means

you&#39;re never more than ten steps from a death
drop, again kind of like your mum and pies.

Of all the many times that I died in this
game, about 60% of them were from being knocked

off a ledge and 30% were from failing to grab
a ledge because the PS4 analog sticks misbehaved.

But Salty Sancho&#39;s flinging fuckery was also
its downfall, because the final boss somehow

managed to clip me into a wall in such a way
that it couldn&#39;t hit me but I could hit him

because I was using a greatsword about half
the length of my dick.

I then beat him with ease, thinking to myself
&quot;Well, I was probably just about to win anyway,&quot;

and that, people, is how easy it is to fall
to the dark side.

Mind you, some of the flying bosses fucked
me up by initiating their attacks from off-screen,

so I guess we can call it even on the naughty
cheating front, Salty Sancho.

On the whole I seem to remember enjoying my
time with Saltine Crackers but then I&#39;ve never
been the same since the stroke.

As you may have noticed I have trouble moving
past the Dark Souls comparison so it&#39;s possibly
struggling to find an identity.

The cartoony art style is pretty appropriate
since the game as a whole feels like a big-headed

chibi version of Dark Souls, Marlon Brando
midget style, with its smaller, kinda samey

environments and more frequent boss fights
that make it feel thinly spread.

I don&#39;t know how much of my absorption came
from the game itself and how much came from

it reminding me of my happy place, but who
gives a shit.

It&#39;s Dark Souls with Symphony of the Night
plugged into the gaps and I like both games

so I&#39;M having a blow job while snacking on
fun-size Mars bars.
